Cost-efficient measurement of room-level heat output from hydronic radiators is a major barrier to large-scale implementation of Economic Model Predictive Control (EMPC) in residential space heating for demand-side management. This paper therefore presents a novel EMPC strategy for hydronic radiators that relies on measurements of radiator pipe temperatures as a proxy for the radiator heat output, thus eliminating the need for costly flow-based meters at each radiator in a building. Simulation-based experiments indicate that the proposed proxy-based EMPC matches the performance of its heat-based counterpart. The proxy-based EMPC achieved a 16.6 % cost reduction compared to the heat-based EMPC's 16.8 %, with no comfort violations in both cases. Furthermore, the strategy shows resilience towards uncertainties in the user-estimated radiator exponent and maximum heating capacity. The proposed EMPC scheme also allows system operators to fine-tune the balance between cost savings and return temperatures using the proxy's upper limit. The findings presented in this paper suggest that the proposed proxy-based EMPC scheme provides a practical pathway for broader applications of EMPC in hydronic-based space heating with the prospect of unlocking significant load shifting potential, cost savings for end-users, and enhanced efficiency in individual and collective energy systems. Keywords Economic model predictive control Hydronic radiators Co-simulations Load-shifting Room-level heating Data availability Data will be made available on request. EMPC of space heating in residential buildings should be managed on room level to maximize the load shifting potential while ensuring thermal comfort for the residents. This is also the suggested approach in several simulation-based studies, see e.g. Refs. [7–9] to mention a few, and in experimental studies [10–13]. However, while EMPC on room level has demonstrated load shifting potential, its transition from academic research to large-scale practical application in buildings encounters several barriers. A major barrier according to Killian and Kozek [14] and Knudsen et al. [13] is to come up with cost-effective concepts for room-based EMPC. Additional capital costs for the realization of EMPC should thus be minimized like in Hedegaard et al. [15] who introduced an EMPC concept where the need for investing in equipment for local weather data measurements was eliminated. There have also been several research-based efforts to minimize the capital cost for obtaining a control model fit for EMPC – a process that is a time-consuming (and thus expensive) part of implementing an EMPC in practice [16–18]. Recently, Knudsen et al. [13] demonstrated experimentally that sufficient predictive performance can be obtained by training a linear black-box model thus reducing the modeling effort. However, there are still several practical barriers to the cost-efficient realization of EMPC at room level in residential buildings; the paper by Amato et al. [19] provides an extensive list of barriers identified in a recent field experiment. A critical barrier to the realization of a room-level EMPC is obtaining the measurement of the space heating output from individual radiators, especially in a cost-efficient way. This is critical as a room-level EMPC relies on measurements of the heat output in the room to identify the parameters of a control model, and to update state estimates during operation. The state-of-the-art for large-scale measurement of heat consumption in residential buildings is metering on building level using 1 m that measures the total heat consumption for space heating, domestic hot water preparation, and heat losses [20]. Real buildings are rarely equipped with more than a central heat meter which is likely why many studies on EMPC for heating systems treat the building as one fully-mixed thermal zone [13,21–23]. In simulation-based studies of room-level EMPC, the practical challenge of obtaining heat output at room-level is conveniently ignored [8,9,15,24–26]. Some experimental studies turn to electric heaters which offer simple equipment for measurements of heat output [27–29] but this is not a solution for buildings heated by hydronic radiators. In the case of hydronic radiators, it is possible to install dedicated meters for each radiator; however, this is not feasible due to capital and maintenance costs. To elaborate, heat meters for individual radiators present several practical challenges. 1) High initial costs: Heat meters typically cost several hundred euros per unit, making their installation across multiple rooms in a building a significant investment. 2) Installation complexity: Retrofitting existing radiators with heat meters requires modifications to the piping system, which can be invasive and time-consuming. 3) Calibration needs. To ensure accurate readings, heat meters require periodic calibration. This is particularly crucial for clamp-on ultrasonic-based meters, which are often used in retrofit applications. 4) Infrastructure limitations: Off-the-shelf heat meters are generally not battery-operated, necessitating connection to the building's electrical system. Furthermore, they often lack built-in wireless data transmission capabilities, complicating data collection and management. Amato et al. [30] suggested a novel dual-zone EMPC concept that avoided investments in additional heat meters for EMPC of space heating in single-family homes with a hydronic radiator system. However, while this approach might work for some residential buildings, it is not generally applicable for homes with several distinct thermal zones. Zong et al. [12] used a control strategy where radiator valves were either fully open or fully closed. Thus, the heat output at room level is known if the radiator heat output at a fully open valve position is known. However, in real-world hydronic systems, the heat output at a fully open valve is rarely known a priori, and this local heat output in a larger hydronic heating system may even vary over time due to varying supply temperature and pressure conditions. Bünning et al. [31] utilized information on valve opening status to approximate heat consumption assuming a linear and constant relationship between valve opening and heat power. However, this may not be a practical approach as most valves do not have a linear characteristic, and the characteristic in real buildings is often not constant due to varying pressure and supply temperature, see e.g. Amato et al. [21]. The above review makes it evident that there is a lack of cost-efficient measurement of room-level heat output from hydronic radiators which is a major barrier to large-scale implementation of EMPC for residential space heating. This paper presents a proposal for a novel method to obtain information about the real-time heat output from an individual hydronic radiator, based on the radiator's pipes temperature measurements as a proxy for heat input, and its implementation within an EMPC formulation. This approach offers a more scalable solution compared to more expensive flow-based heat measurements. The paper is structured as follows. The method section describes a proposed proxy-based EMPC, its underlying theory, and a virtual setup for a proof-of-concept simulation. This is followed by a section featuring results which subsequently are discussed and concluded upon. 2 Method 2.1 Baseline EMPC A typical model predictive control framework for operating building energy systems is notably versatile, accommodating a wide array of optimization formulations [14,32]. In the context of EMPC where minimizing energy costs is the objective, a linear programming approach is often both convenient and effective for describing the optimization problem: (1) J = min Q ˙ h ∑ k = 0 N − 1 c k Q ˙ h k This is subject to the following constraints: (1.a) x ( k + 1 ) = A x ( k ) + B Q ˙ h ( k ) + E d ( k ) + K e ( k ) (1.b) T r o o m ( k ) = C x ( k ) (1.c) 0 ≤ Q ˙ h ( k ) ≤ Q ˙ h , max ( k ) (1.d) T r o o m , min ( k + 1 ) ≤ T r o o m ( k + 1 ) ≤ T r o o m , max ( k + 1 ) (1.e) Δ T r o o m , min ( k + 1 ) ] ≤ Δ T r o o m ( k + 1 ) ≤ Δ T r o o m , max ( k + 1 ) (1.f) x ( 0 ) = x ˆ ( 0 ) The objective function in equation (1) minimizes the cumulative cost of space heating over the prediction horizon N , where c ( k ) represents a time-varying heating cost and Q ˙ h ( k ) denotes the heating power at a time step k = { 0 , 1 , … , N − 1 } . Constraints (1.a) and (1.b) are the state and output equations of a discrete-time state-space model in its innovations form which represent the thermal behavior of the building. The state vector x ∈ R ² represents the internal states of the second-order black box model. In this study, we employed the Prediction Error Minimization (PEM) method for system identification [33]. The PEM method estimates all model parameters, including the A, B, C, E, and Kalman gain K, by iteratively minimizing the squared difference between the model's one-step ahead predictions and the actual system outputs. We used the canonical controllable form for the state-space model, where the C matrix is structured as C = [ 1 0 ] . This formulation allows us to interpret the first state x 1 as the room temperature. The second state x 2 , while not directly mappable to a specific physical quantity, captures additional dynamics of the thermal system. Together, these two states provide a reduced-order representation of the room's thermal behavior. The input vector u represents control actions, which in this study was the radiator heat power ( Q ˙ h ) . The disturbance vector d accounts for uncontrollable external factors, which in this study was outdoor air temperature ( T e x t ) and solar irradiance ( Q ˙ s ) . The observable output y is the room air temperature ( T r o o m ). The innovation term e is the output prediction error which is used to correct the model predictions. In the optimization problem, e ( k ) can only be known up to the current time step ( k = 0 ) , as future prediction errors are unknown. Therefore, e ( 0 ) is set to the current known value, while e ( k ) is assumed to be zero for all future time steps ( k ≥ 1 ) . This assumption of zero for future innovations is justified because the expected value of the innovation term is zero, which follows from the properties of the system identification process. Specifically, techniques like PEM yield models where prediction errors have zero mean for the training data, making zero the best estimate for future, unknown innovations. The system dynamics are encapsulated in the following matrices. • A ∈ R 2 x 2 describes the evolution of states without external inputs • B ∈ R 2 x 1 maps the influence of control actions on the states • E ∈ R 2 x 2 links disturbances to state changes • C ∈ R 1 x 2 correlates states to observable outputs • K ∈ R 2 x 1 (Kalman gain) refines state predictions based on the innovation While these matrices can be derived from physical principles (white-box modeling), this approach is often impractical. Instead, a data-driven approach using empirical time series of system inputs ( u , d ) and outputs ( y ) is typically employed. This method results in either grey-box models, which incorporate prior knowledge of the physical configuration, or black-box models that represent purely empirical input-output relationships. Constraints (1.c) define the operational limits for the radiator's heat output. Constraints (1.d) and (1.e) specify the acceptable room temperature bounds and rate-of-change, respectively. Although not shown in the mathematical program for simplicity, slack variables are introduced in our implementation to transform these into soft constraints, ensuring solution feasibility. Constraint (1.f) establishes the initial state at the beginning of the prediction horizon, aligning the model with real-world dynamics based on current measurements. Since x ( 0 ) is not directly measurable, a state estimate, x ˆ ( 0 ) is derived from the previous state estimate x ˆ ( − 1 ) and recent measurements ( k = − 1 ) of Q ˙ h and d : (2) x ˆ ( 0 ) = A x ˆ ( − 1 ) + B Q ˙ h ( − 1 ) + E d ( − 1 ) + K ( T r o o m ( − 1 ) − C x ˆ ( − 1 ) ) Implementing this heat-based EMPC for room-level control requires heat measurements at the room-level: historical heat output is essential for constructing the thermal room model, and real-time heat measurements are necessary to continuously updating the state estimate ( x ˆ ) . Furthermore, knowledge of the maximum radiator heat output ( Q ˙ h , max ) is assumed, which presents a significant challenge due to its dependency on variable conditions such as supply temperature and system pressure. 2.2 EMPC with proxy heat measurement Given the cost and the impracticalities of conducting flow-based heat measurements for individual radiators, it is proposed to introduce the use of a proxy variable based on radiator pipe temperatures. Temperature sensors are relatively inexpensive and non-intrusive compared to flow-based heat measurement devices, providing a potentially more scalable alternative for practical implementation. The proposed proxy variable ( u p ) leverages the steady-state heat output formula for a radiator, as detailed in Ref. [34]: (3) Q ˙ r = α Δ T n = α u p Here, Q ˙ r denotes the heat power emitted from the radiator including both convection and radiation. The constant α is influenced by the size of the radiator while the radiator exponent n usually ranging from 1.1 to 1.4 reflects the balance between the radiation and convection components [35]. The term Δ T represents the temperature difference between the mean water temperature within the radiator and the room temperature. The last equality posits u p = Δ T n as the proposed proxy variable, where Δ T can be calculated using the logarithmic mean temperature difference: (4) Δ T lg = T i n − T o u t ln ( T i n − T r o o m T o u t − T r o o m ) To employ Δ T lg n as a proxy for radiator heat consumption, it is necessary to acquire the inlet and outlet temperatures ( T i n , T o u t ) , alongside the room temperature ( T r o o m ) and the radiator exponent n . Assuming room temperature measurements are already available, the inlet and outlet temperatures can be deduced from the surface temperatures of the radiator inlet and outlet pipes. With the proxy defined in Equation (4), the heat-based optimization in equations 1-1.f can be recast terms of u p . In Equation (5), B p maps the proxy input u p to the states and replaced the original B mapping Q ˙ h to the states: (5) B Q ˙ h [ k ] = B α u p [ k ] = B p u p [ k ] The new optimization can be obtained by simply replacing Q ˙ h with u p in the objective function in equation (6), omitting α as it is a constant not affecting the solution. Constraint (6.a) is also adjusted accordingly: (6) J = min u p ∑ k = 0 N − 1 c k u p k subject to the following constraints: (6.a) x ( k + 1 ) = A x ( k ) + B p u p ( k ) + E d ( k ) + K e ( k ) (6.b) T r o o m ( k ) = C x ( k ) (6.c) 0 ≤ u p ( k ) ≤ u p , max ( k ) (6.d) T r o o m , min ( k + 1 ) ≤ T r o o m ( k + 1 ) ≤ T r o o m , max ( k + 1 ) (6.e) Δ T r o o m , min ( k + 1 ) ≤ Δ T r o o m ( k + 1 ) ≤ Δ T r o o m , max ( k + 1 ) (6.f) x ( 0 ) = x ˆ ( 0 ) The upper limit on u p in the proxy-based MPC can be derived by choosing a maximum return temperature ( T o u t , max ) and assuming specific inlet and room temperatures: (7) u p , max = Δ T lg , max 1.3 = ( T i n − T o u t , max ln ( T i n − T r o o m T o u t , max − T r o o m ) ) 1.3 The proxy-based optimization thus offers a convenient way to approximate the input constraints and at the same time it provides a means to control the maximum return temperature. This is a distinct benefit of this novel formulation of the optimization problem as many district heating companies penalize return temperatures exceeding a specific maximum value. Finally, the initial state estimate must also be determined using the proxy input, which is done by replacing the term B Q ˙ h ( − 1 ) in Formula (2) with B p u p ( − 1 ) . The solution to the proxy-based optimization problem is a sequence of proxy inputs over the prediction horizon. However, the optimal proxy inputs are never applied directly; instead, the first optimal proxy input is used to predict the optimal room temperature T r o o m * ( 1 ) in the next time step, and then this temperature is applied as setpoint for the radiator thermostat, T r o o m s e t . 2.3 Virtual test setup The performance of the proposed proxy-based EMPC framework was evaluated within a virtual environment where a dynamic multi-layered hydronic radiator was modeled in Python and integrated with an EnergyPlus room model as illustrated in Fig. 1 . The EnergyPlus Python API [36,37] was used to enable co-simulation. The EnergyPlus model captured the thermal dynamics of a thermal zone (room), specifically determining the air temperature ( T r o o m ) by accounting for the convective ( Q ˙ c o n v e c t i o n ) and radiative ( Q ˙ r a d i a t i o n ) heat outputs from the radiator. The EMPC informed by the inlet ( T i n ) and outlet temperatures ( T o u t ) of the radiator along with T r o o m and forecasts of solar radiation ( Q ˙ s ) , external temperature ( T e x t ) , and energy prices ( c ) , computed the optimal room air temperature and applied it as set point ( T r o o m s e t ) for the radiator thermostat. A Proportional-Integral (PI) regulated the radiator valve opening ( U ) to adjust the water mass flow ( m ˙ w ) , thereby tracking the setpoint. An hourly time step was used throughout all experiments. The following sections provide further details on the individual parts of the co-simulation setup in Fig. 1. 2.3.1 Case-study EnergyPlus room The geometry of the room used as a case-study is illustrated in Fig. 2 . The window facing the outdoors is situated on the east-facing wall. The south-facing wall is also facing the outdoors; all other surfaces were modeled as internal partitions facing rooms maintained at a constant temperature of 21 °C. Construction layers and material properties are detailed in Table 1 . A constant infiltration rate of 0.3 h−1 was used in this model. The climatic data employed for the simulations was a typical meteorological year for Copenhagen, Denmark (DNK_Copenhagen.061800_IWEC.epw). We purposefully excluded occupancy-related disturbances to isolate and evaluate the EMPC's performance without confounding variables. This approach allows a clear comparison between the traditional and the proxy-based EMPC Radiator Model. A detailed model representing the thermal dynamics of the radiator is needed to evaluate the performance of the proposed method. EnergyPlus only offers a static radiator model, so the multi-layered dynamic radiator model by Pedersen et al. [9] was employed in this study. Fig. 3 shows how this model of a radiator is segmented into N S horizontal sections connected in series and each segment has a heat balance, leading to an N S -dimensional system of differential equations. Thermographic studies validate this approach, supporting nearly uniform horizontal sections for the radiator [9]. For a given section j , the heat balance is expressed as: (8) d Q s t o r e d , j d t = Q ˙ i n , j − Q ˙ o u t , j Where Q s t o r e d , j is the heat stored in section j , and Q ˙ i n , j and Q ˙ o u t , j represent the power fluxes into and out of that section. The behavior of each section is further elaborated as: (9) C R a d 1 N S d T j d t = c p , w m ˙ w T j − 1 − T j − U A N S T j − T r o o m n Here, T j is the temperature in the j'th section, C R a d is the combined heat capacity of the water and radiator material, c p , w is the specific heat capacity of the water, m ˙ w is the mass flow rate, n is the radiator exponent, U is the radiator's heat transfer coefficient and A is the surface area. To find the temperatures in each section, we integrated the system of differential equations using the Runge-Kutta method (RK45). The total radiator heat power, Q ˙ r , was obtained by summing up the contribution from all sections: (10) Q ˙ r = U A N S ∑ j = 1 N S T j − T r o o m n The split fraction between convection and radiation was determined according to Ref. [9]: (11) β R = β R , N o m T r o o m + Δ T lg 4 − T r o o m 4 T r o o m + Δ T lg , N o m 4 − T r o o m 4 Δ T lg Δ T lg , N o m n Where β R , N o m denotes the radiative fraction under standard conditions, Δ T lg and Δ T lg , N o m represents the logarithmic mean temperature difference under current and standard conditions, respectively. Given β R , the convection fraction is β C = 1 − β R , leading to the respective powers: (12) Q ˙ r a d i a t i o n = β R Q ˙ r (13) Q ˙ c o n v e c t i o n = β C Q ˙ r In this study, the nominal heat capacity of the simulated radiator was set to 892 W. This capacity is sufficient to maintain the indoor temperature at the setpoint during the dimensioning outdoor temperature, with an additional 15 % capacity. This oversize is common practice to be on the safe side. Table 2 lists the specific parameter values. The integration of the radiator's radiant and convective power outputs from this radiator model into the EnergyPlus model was done via an ‘ElectricEquipment’ object, reflecting that the convective heat affects the room air directly, while the radiative heat impacts the surfaces. 2.3.2 Radiator thermostat model A discrete Proportional-Integral (PI) controller, shown in Equation (14), was implemented to enable the radiator to track the temperature set point, T r o o m s e t , determined by the EMPC. (14) u ( i ) = K p e ( i ) + K i ∑ i = 1 n t e ( i ) Δ t Unlike the EMPC, the PI controller operates at a timestep of 60s. To avoid a buildup of the integral term an anti-windup mechanism stopped the integration when saturation was reached. The control signal u ( i ) adjusted the radiator valve opening, where u ( i ) = 0 denoted a fully closed valve, and u ( i ) = 1 represented a fully open valve, allowing maximum water flow, m ˙ w , max . For this study, the controller parameters were set to K p = 2 and K i = 0.01 . 2.3.3 Simulation tests The virtual test setup was used to perform a range of performance tests of the proposed proxy-based EMPC. The first set of experiments had the purpose of evaluating its predictive performance and the EMPC performance. First, the virtual test setup system was excited using an hourly pseudo-random setpoints between 20 °C and 23.5 °C and with a maximum of one-degree change per hour to create data suitable for system identification. Then, models were trained on the heat power ( Q ˙ h ) and the proxy input ( u p ) , respectively, and their performance was compared the measured room temperature. The performance of the two models were then evaluated in an EMPC experiment. In real-world settings, the precise value of the radiator exponent ( n ) might be unknown; however, this value is needed to compute the proxy input. Simulations for a range of n -values around the true value were therefore conducted to assess the robustness of the proxy-based method against inaccuracies in the estimation of n . An experiment featuring the variability of water flow and return temperature using the proposed proxy-based EMPC was also conducted as such variability may result in unwanted problems like wear and tear of the radiator valve, audible noise, fluctuating radiator surface temperatures which might cause discomfort, and elevated return temperature which can compromise district heating system efficiency and lead to customer penalties. 3 Results 3.1 System identification Fig. 4 depicts data from the experiment that generated data for system identification. Fig. 5 compares the room temperature predictions from the models trained on the heat power ( Q ˙ h ) and the proxy input ( u p ) , respectively, to the measured room temperature. The top plot shows one-step ahead predictions, reflecting short-term accuracy, while the bottom plot offers 24-step ahead predictions, emphasizing long-term forecasting. The Q ˙ h -based model have high fit percentages for both the short (92.6 %) and long-term (90.0 %) predictions. In contrast, the u p -based model yields more moderate fits of 75.5 % and 72.5 %. The identified matrices (A, B, E, C, and K) for both the heat-based and proxy-based models are provided in Appendix A. While system stability was not explicitly enforced as a constraint in the data-driven identification process, a subsequent analysis of eigenvalues confirms that the open-loop system (A) is stable for both models, which aligns with the expected behavior of building thermal dynamics. Furthermore, the estimator dynamics (characterized by A-KC) are also stable for both models. Specifically, all eigenvalues of both A and A-KC have magnitudes less than 1, satisfying the stability criterion for discrete-time systems. 3.2 EMPC performance The results from simulations of the Baseline EMPC and the proxy-based EMPC were compared against a PI-controller tracking a constant 20 °C room temperature. The simulation period was after the system identification period. Fig. 6 shows the results of this comparison. The top plot shows indoor temperatures for the proxy-based EMPC (red), the Baseline EMPC (blue), and the PI controller (black). The green horizontal lines indicate the temperature constraints. The middle plot shows the corresponding heat consumption alongside the district heating price (green), while the bottom plot shows the outdoor temperature and solar radiation. Both EMPC strategies adhere to the temperature constraints ( 20 °C ≤ T r o o m ≤ 22.5 °C ) and the rate-of-change constraints ( − 1 °C ≤ Δ T r o o m ≤ 1 °C ) . They exhibit similar load-shifting behavior with pronounced preheating during low-cost nighttime periods. However, the Baseline EMPC also uniquely preheats slightly before evening peaks. Compared to the PI controller, the Baseline EMPC increased energy consumption by 8 % but reduced costs by 16.8 %. The proxy-based EMPC led to a 7 % rise in energy use but achieved a 16.6 % cost reduction which is on par with the Baseline EMPC despite the lower fit percentage of the proxy-based model. It is noted that the nominal heat capacity of the radiator (892 W) was never utilized, despite the upper bound on the heat power or proxy input being set to infinite. This is because the temperature rate-of-change constraint activates first, effectively limiting the applicable heat input. 3.3 Radiator exponent uncertainty Fig. 7 displays the cost savings and model fit (based on simulation errors) from the experiment featuring simulations of the proxy-based method using different estimations of n . The results indicate consistent EMPC performance for n between 1.0 and 1.5 suggesting that the proxy-based method is resilient within this interval. 3.4 Water flow and return temperature analysis Fig. 8 depicts the radiator water flow and temperatures in the inlet ( j = 1 ) , midpoint ( j = 10 ) and outlet ( J = 20 ) sections of the radiator as defined in Fig. 3 when operated using the proposed proxy-based EMPC and a constant setpoint (baseline). While the baseline maintains a steady water flow, the EMPC exhibits more dynamic fluctuations due to the low-level controller adjusting to changing setpoints which potentially could lead to the problems mentioned in section 2.1.4. To address these problems, we explored the effects of setting an upper limit on u p . Experiments up until now did not include an upper limit on u p (i.e., u p , max = ∞ ) but relied on the rate-of-change constraint to prevent the EMPC from ever wanting to use inputs exceeding what the radiator model could support. Fig. 9 showcases the system behavior with u p , max ≤ 55 corresponding to a maximum outlet temperature of 27 °C (assuming T i n = 70 °C and T r o o m = 20 °C in Equation (7)). The system stabilizes more swiftly at a reduced flow despite rapid initial flow changes resulting in a lower average return temperature. However, it is worth noting that limiting u p , max alone does not completely eliminate the EMPC-induced water flow fluctuations. To achieve this, adjustments to the low-level PI-controller would be required which is left for future works. A flow-weighted return temperature was calculated to quantify the impact of applying different input constraints ( u p , max ) : (15) T 20 , w e i g h t e d = ∑ i T 20 i m ˙ w i ∑ i m ˙ w i where T 20 ( i ) is the outlet temperature at the i'th simulation time step (every 60 s). Fig. 10 illustrates the balance between u p , max and the trade-off between cost and flow-weighted return temperature: As u p , max increased, the cost was reduced – but the weighted return temperature increased. Note that if cost minimization is the sole objective, an unbounded u p , max can be chosen even though there is an actual limit to how much the radiator can heat. However, this limit is never used if a reasonable temperature rate-of-change constraint is implemented to respect thermal comfort. This realization simplifies practical implementation significantly as the maximum radiator capacity does not need to be known. 4 Discussion The simulation-based experiments yielded several interesting results. For system identification, the proxy-based model showed reduced prediction accuracy compared to the heat-based model. This drop likely stems from approximation errors during transient periods, as the proxy input is a steady-state approximation of emitted heat. However, this decrease in prediction accuracy was not reflected in the EMPC performance, where the cost savings and comfort of the proxy-based EMPC are on par with the heat-based EMPC. Furthermore, the results demonstrated that setting the upper bound on heat and proxy input to infinity did not compromise performance. This was because the temperature rate-of-change constraint was always activated before the maximum heat input could be applied. This approach assumes that the radiator is slightly oversized (in our study, the radiator is 15 % oversized), which means that a 1-degree change per hour is achieved before the maximum capacity is applied. However, if a faster temperature change is allowed, this method might not work optimally, though such rapid changes are not recommended for occupant comfort. Alternatively, u p , max could be calculated based on a user-chosen maximum return temperature using the relationship in Equation (7). This approach reduces the upper bound on u p , max below the maximum capacity to manage the maximum return temperature more directly. For future works, the following areas seems worth exploring. • Real-world Implementation: A pilot study in actual residential settings would provide insights into the practical challenges and benefits of implementing the proxy-based EMPC. • Optimizing PID for EMPC: Investigating modifications to Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controllers, ensuring better integration with EMPC applications. • Broadening the scope: The proposed concept could be adapted for other heating systems, like floor heating, and could – with some modifications – also be applied in systems where a heat pump is the heat source. • Multi-objective optimization: The adaptability of buildings to varying operational needs of the district heating system can be further enhanced by e.g. incorporating time-varying costs for return temperatures. It is acknowledged that occupancy can significantly impact practical applications, but addressing these effects goes beyond the scope of this study, which focuses on the core efficiency of the proxy-based approach. Future research will need to develop strategies to handle such variables and to fully realize the potential of EMPC in real-world scenarios. 5 Conclusion A room-level EMPC strategy for hydronic radiators that relies on measurements of radiator pipe temperatures as a proxy for the radiator heat output was proposed. This proxy-based EMPC performs on par with power-based EMPC and is therefore a cost-efficient alternative to a power-based EMPC which would require installation of a flow-based heat meter at each radiator in a building. The proxy-based approach also proved resilient to uncertainties regarding the radiator exponent and maximum heating capacity. Furthermore, the definition of the proxy-based EMPC provides system operators with a straightforward mechanism to balance the trade-off between cost savings and return temperatures through a user-specified maximum proxy input. Given the current state of development, the proposed proxy-based EMPC seems like a promising step towards a more practical and widespread application of EMPC for hydronic space-heating that could activate a significant demand response resource, offering cost-savings to the end-users and promoting a more efficient operation of the overall energy system. coredata.dc:description: Cost-efficient measurement of room-level heat output from hydronic radiators is a major barrier to large-scale implementation of Economic Model Predictive Control (EMPC) in residential space heating for demand-side management. This paper therefore presents a novel EMPC strategy for hydronic radiators that relies on measurements of radiator pipe temperatures as a proxy for the radiator heat output, thus eliminating the need for costly flow-based meters at each radiator in a building. Simulation-based experiments indicate that the proposed proxy-based EMPC matches the performance of its heat-based counterpart. The proxy-based EMPC achieved a 16.6 % cost reduction compared to the heat-based EMPC's 16.8 %, with no comfort violations in both cases. Furthermore, the strategy shows resilience towards uncertainties in the user-estimated radiator exponent and maximum heating capacity. The proposed EMPC scheme also allows system operators to fine-tune the balance between cost savings and return temperatures using the proxy's upper limit. The findings presented in this paper suggest that the proposed proxy-based EMPC scheme provides a practical pathway for broader applications of EMPC in hydronic-based space heating with the prospect of unlocking significant load shifting potential, cost savings for end-users, and enhanced efficiency in individual and collective energy systems.
